Description: Solid-cast mirror in copper alloy; of oblong, almost circular, shape with a simple projecting tang to which was attached a missing handle (in wood?); tang ending with two engraved reared volute; restored recto presenting well polished surface; on verso, remains of fine textile (maybe linen?) visible in corrosion; metal relatively well preserved but quite corroded.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Oriental Institute, University of Chicago. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Mirrors had more than a pure domestic function. According to iconographic and archaeological evidences, they could be an object of cult, either offered as an ex-voto or part of the funerary equipment (Robinson 2010, 219-220). Robinson, Z. 2010, ‘Living with Metals in Hellenistic Egypt – New Finds from Heraclion-Thonis’, in D. Robinson and A. Wilson (eds.), Alexandria and the North-West Delta, Oxford, 219–231.

Mirrors with this type of inscribed volute tang are known predominantly from Cyprus (Oberländer 1967, 131-2), though the closest parallel for this piece comes from a 5th century BC tomb on Rhodes (British Museum, 1864,1007.353). Oberländer, P. 1967, Griechische Handspiegel, Hamburg.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (RA.02)
